text:
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to the Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: L.W. Kelly
Address: Rossville, Sask.
Birthplace: London, Eng.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? (My Parents) 1910.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Millwood, Man.
Where had you been living before that? England.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4.
How far was it to your nearest store? 2.1/2 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Daily, if necessary.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Everything Necessary.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Fave Roses.
In what quantities did you buy it? 300 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50.
How much did you use graham flour? Very little.
Whole wheat flour? Mixed in with white flour to make brown bread.
Was flour milled locally? No. How far away? 50 miles. What year? 1910.
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 45¢.
What other grain products did you use? Corn meal for porridge and cake.
Cornmeal? Yes. Whole Wheat? Yes. Farina? Yes.
Other? Crushed wheat for porridge at times.
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes.
How did you grind it? In the ordinary grain cracker.
1. INTERROGATORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? (Mr. Thomas) 1920.

Where did you set up housekeeping? Millwood, Man.

Where had you been living before that? England.

For how many people did you prepare meals? Four.

How far was it to your nearest store? 3 1/4 miles.

How often would a visit be made to the store? Daily.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Everything necessary.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Paynes.

In what quantities did you buy at? 100 lbs.

That was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50.

How much did you use of brown flour? Paynes.

Whole wheat flour? Whole.

Was flour milled locally? No.

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 45¢.

What other grain products did you use? Oats, meal, for porridge and cake.

Cornmeal? Yes.

Other? Rolled wheat for porridge.

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes.

How did you grind it? In the ordinary grain grinder.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...100 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ...About $4.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...Heckman.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...10 lbs.

At what price? ...$2.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Mr. Kerthling of Millwood kept a herd of Jersey cows and we got our milk from him. Later we had a cow on loan.

Butter? ...Yes, often.

Eggs? ...Yes, often.

What was the price of butter? ...About 25¢.

Did you keep eggs for winter? ...Yes.

How? ...In water glasses and sometimes in salt.

Did you make butter? ...Yes.

Cheese? ...Yes, a little later.

What kind of cheese? ...Whole milk.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ...At first, the store in Millwood.

Later, our own killing, usually pork.

How did you get fresh meat? ...As above.

How often did you get fresh meat? ...At first, weekly; later, once or twice a year.

How did you preserve meat? ...Sometimes in brine; otherwise dry-salted or smoked.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ...Yes, at Millwood.

If so, what year was it organized? ...Probably in 1900.

Did you use game? ...Yes.

What kinds? ...Bush and Jack rabbits, partridges, prairie chickens, ducks, and sometimes venison.

For how long? ...Still do.

What part did fish play in the family diet? ...At first, we lived beside the Assiniboine River and we had fish daily. Later, we caught them in a trap and salted and smoked them.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ...Some used in each way.

Kinds? ...Jackfish, suckers, and goldeye.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? ...English Blend... At what price? About .40¢ lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) ...Ground...

Price? ...30¢ lb... What other beverages were used? ...Coffee...

...Sometimes roasted and ground, relax with chocolate...

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? ...25¢...

Could you get potatoes at the store? ...Yes...

If not, where from? ...Neighbouring farmers...

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1911-1912

Potatoes ...Yes... Cabbage ...Yes... Carrots ...Yes... Onions ...Yes...

Turnips ...Yes... Beets ...Yes...

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? ...Quantities...

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? ...By the box...

What weight? ...20 lbs... How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ...Both...

What was the price of prunes? ...Price...

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)? ...Apples; peaches; raisins and currants by the box.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? ...Yes...

peas? ...Yes... corn? ...Yes... beans? ...Yes... Saskatoons? ...Yes...

other foods? ...Gadled orange, lemon and citron peel...

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? ...1910...

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ...Year...

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? ...Fish 1912... Meat 1913...

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? ...Yes...

To what extent? ...150 qts canned fruit... 25 qts jam... 30 jelly...

Did you make your own vinegar? ...Yes...

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? ...Royal yeast, cakes...sometimes...

Did you make yeast for your own use? ...yes...... Using starter? ...yes... sometimes we made yeast cakes using cornmeal and sour milk

Using hops? ...yes............. Salt rising? ..........................

Did you buy baking powder? ...yes.......... Baking soda? ...yes.........

Cream of tartar? .......yea........ Did you make your own baking powder?

...sometimes..................................................................................

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? ... Regal, Yeast, Cake, Appetites...
Did you make yeast for your own use? ... Yes ... Using starter? ... Yes ... Milk
Using hops? ... Yes ... Sometimes we made yeast cakes using cornmeal and sour milk
Did you buy baking powder? ... Yes ...
Crust of tart? ... Yes ... Did you take your own baking powder?
Sometimes

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ...River at first...50 yds...well later 175 yds...

How far was this water from your home? ...as above...

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...pail; later barrel...

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. We still get our water from a well by the pail full for drinking but we have rainwater cistern in the cellar and a hand pump gravity system with range boiler, bath tub and sinks.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ..............River, 4 ft., 500 ft., 50 ft., 25 ft., well, later, 175 yds.

If so, how was this water from your house? ..............is above.

Here was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) ....Redi, later, barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. We still get our water from a well by the pailful for drinking but we have rainwater distern in the cellar and a hand pump gravity system with range boiler, bath tub and sinks.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ...wood ashes, lye, etc.

If you made your own, did you use lye? ...wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? ...soap, soap and others

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ...wood

Where did you get your fuel? ...cut it in the bluffs

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible, continued to use wood exclusively until 1940 started to use coal part time. 1948 coal exclusively until 1950 and now use electricity for perhaps 5% of our cooking. We have used coal oil for some summer cooking in the past ten years.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ...not since leaving England

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ...only occasionally in the Summer to save heating the house.

By whom was your first cook stove made? ...Bought of M. Eaton Co.

What year was it purchased? ...1910... Price? ...

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

...iron and tin...

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) ...earthenware and wooden and enamelware

When did you first see enamel ware? ...1910...

Aluminum? ...
13. WAS

DID YOU BUY LAUNDRY SOAP OR MAKE YOUR OWN?

IF YOU MADE YOUR OWN, DID YOU USE Lye? ... YES ... NO ...

WHAT KIND OF LAUNDRY SOAP DID THE CLOTHES NEED TO BE WASHED IN?

14. FUEL

WHAT FUEL DID YOU USE IN THE EARLIEST DAYS? ... WOOD ... GAS ... ELECTRICITY ...

WHERE DID YOU GET YOUR FUEL? ... OUT OF THE GROUND ... FROM A NEIGHBOR ... PURCHASED ...

NOTED ANY CHANGES IN THE USE OF FUELS WHICH HAVE TAKEN PLACE SINCE YOU FIRST STARTED HOUSEHOLDING? ... YES ... NO ...

IF YES, WHEN DID THIS HAPPEN? ... 1940 ... 1950 ... 1960 ...

EXCLUSIVELY UNTIL 1940 STARTED TO USE COAL PART TIME. 1948 COAL EXCLUSIVELY UNTIL 1950 AND NOW USE ELECTRICITY FOR PERHAPS 5% OF OUR COOKING. WE HAVE USED COAL OIL FOR SOME SUMMER COOKING IN THE PAST TEN YEARS.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

FOR COOKING, DID YOU USE AN INDOOR FIREPLACE OR OPEN HEARTH IN THE EARLIEST DAYS? (GIVE DATES) ... YES ... NO ...

DID YOU USE AN OUTDOOR FIRPLACE OR "BACK OVEN" (GIVE DATES) ... ONLY ...

OCCASIONALLY IN THE SUMMER TO SAVE HEATING THE HOUSE.

BY THEN WAS YOUR FIRST COOK STOVE PURCHASED? ... 1910 ... 1920 ... 1930 ...

PRICES?

THAT TYPE OF UTENSILS DID YOU USE? (IRON, COPPER, TIN, IRONWARE)

FOR PREPARING FOOD? (GLASS, EARTHENWARE, WOODEN AND IRONWARE)

WHEN DID YOU FIRST USE THESE MATERIALS?

IRON ... 1800

GLASS ... 1800

EARTHENWARE ... 1800

WOODEN ... 1800

IRONWARE ... 1800

ALUMINUM ... 1800
16. Wrappings and Containers

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Some jams and preserves were put up in earthenware jars these are not seen now these were after put up in tins and these are giving way to more glassware containers. Yeast cakes have been replaced by granulated yeast in envelopes. Cereals are now packaged that were in sacks (cotton) Tea, coffee and molasses that were bulk items are now all packaged at the wholesalers and a great many items are celophane wrapped either wholesale or retail that were formerly weighed locally into paper sacks.

17. Give a Probable Day's Menu (Breakfast, Dinner & Supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge, either rolled oats, cornmeal or perhaps whole wheat crushed or whole, with milk and brown sugar, toasted homemade bread and homemade marmalade or cranberry jelly or jam, tea.

Dinner: Fried salt or smoked pork, potatoes, pig weeds (boiled) (specially) in early summer when vegetables were scarce, thirsty pudding or boiled rice with raisins or with sugar milk and butter, tea.

Supper: Fresh fried or cold canned jack fish or other, fried chipped or left-over potatoes, lettuce, radishes or even dandelion leaves in season some kind of canned or preserved fruit, johnny cake or boiled cake or occasionally a fruit cake which probably contained dried saskatoons or homemade candied peel and might even contain acorns in place of nuts.

1911: The four members of the Kelly family as listed below.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

1910............. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time. George Kelly (Father) 44; Elizabeth Kelly 45 (mother); Arthur Kelly 21 and Lawrence Kelly 13. Mr Gough 58

Lettice Gough 20; Hugh Gough 15;

two roast roosters and a baked ham, homemade parsnip and rhubarb wine; mashed potatoes, mashed turnips, boiled parsnips, various kinds of pickles; Cranberry jelly (local), bread and buns, butter, tea, English Xmas pudding.

Mince tarts, the pudding had brandy poured over it and burnt off with a pretty blue flame. Some of the same found its way into the mince-meat. Last but not least a Christmas cake as only my Mother knew how to make, this was always in tiers usually four of them and lasted for a couple of months. I should have kept for that long so that anyone that came along later could have a taste. Mother was justly proud of her cake; it was probably made several weeks before and went through success stages of icing. The pudding was often one that was made a year before.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

It would not be true that we were ever nearly starved, but it is certain that we were very short of many things that we would like to have had in the '30s and we were getting by on about $5.00 per month for a family of 3 adults and 4 children, we had vegetables and flour but the money had to cover all items that we were unable to produce ourselves including clothing.
16. **THINNING AND CULTIVATING**

In the springtime and early fall, thinning plants and seedlings. In the fall, thinning plants and seedlings.

17. **GLUTEN FREE**

Gluten-free diets are becoming more common. Gluten-free products are now available in most grocery stores.

18. **CHRISTMAS DINNER**

Christmas dinner is a special occasion for many families. Here are some traditional recipes:

- **Main Course:** Roast turkey or ham
- **Side Dishes:** Mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce, green beans
- **Dessert:** Pecan pie or apple crisp

19. **LOCAL PRODUCE**

Locally grown produce is becoming more popular. It is fresher and often more nutritious than produce that has traveled long distances.

20. **FAMILY HISTORY**

Family history is an important part of our heritage. It helps us understand where we come from and who we are.

21. **CLOTHING**

Clothing is an essential part of our daily lives. It keeps us warm and dry, and helps us express ourselves.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The main difference is in the variety of foods and the methods of packaging. We were unable to get such things as bologna or canned meats, spread cheese, quick yeast, prepared meals incans, quick cooking oats or many of the flaked or granulated cereals, canned milk, or powdered; no frozen foods or home refrigeration, ice cream was made at home from the ice house, there were no soap powders, flakes or detergents; a lot of the laundry and some toilet soap was made at home; few people had soft water cisterns and many used a wooden barrel of hard water into which wood ashes was mixed and allowed to settle for softening water.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homogrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The main difference is in the variety of foods and the methods of packaging. We were unable to get such things as bologna or canned meats, spread cheese, quick yeast, prepared meals incans, quick cooking oats or many of the flaked or granulated cereals, canned milk, or powdered; no frozen foods or home refrigeration, ice cream was made at home from the ice house, there were no soap powders, flakes or detergents; a lot of the laundry and some toilet soap was made at home; few people had soft water cisterns and many used a wooden barrel of hard water into which wood ashes was mixed and allowed to settle for softening water.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].
